Title: Linking forum posts - bioinfomethods-04-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: DNA fragments for sequencing in slide11
Input.posts:
Hi Folks, Can, please, someone help me to understand a picture in slide 10 (wrong in the name of the thread), Lecture 6 [=box1 (lab6)]. It shows that the primers at 5' end of the top strand are always green and at 5'-end of the reverse strand are always red. So ligation is unidirectional. Is it just simplification to make it easier for students to understand? Or is it really so? Then my question is how is it done. Any comment will be appreciated.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Anon, in Slide 19 for Lecture 6 (Box 1 of Lab 6), the cartoon shows that the linkers are uni-directional, or at least different at each end. There's some molecular biology 'magic' going on behind the scenes to make this happen. The first linker could be a blunt ligation (and thus would get attached to both ends) and then a digestion step could create a 'sticky' end to which the 2nd linker gets ligated. Only those fragments that have two different linkers would work in subsequent steps. Alternately, fragments might be partially digested with two different enzymes having different sticky ends and then the linkers could be ligated. Again, only fragments with both kinds of linkers would work in subsequent steps. TL;DR: yes, it is a simplification. Best, Nick
Instructor's post : Hi Anon, in Slide 19 for Lecture 6 (Box 1 of Lab 6), the cartoon shows that the linkers are uni-directional, or at least different at each end. There's some molecular biology 'magic' going on behind the scenes to make this happen. The first linker could be a blunt ligation (and thus would get attached to both ends) and then a digestion step could create a 'sticky' end to which the 2nd linker gets ligated. Only those fragments that have two different linkers would work in subsequent steps. Alternately, fragments might be partially digested with two different enzymes having different sticky ends and then the linkers could be ligated. Again, only fragments with both kinds of linkers would work in subsequent steps. TL;DR: yes, it is a simplification. Best, Nick
Upvotes:
1

Input.threadtitle: Information lost in lecture 6 slide 5 in pdf
Input.posts:
I have submitted a bug report and replicate it here just in case: The figure on a slide 5 of a lecture 6 (about costs of human gut microbiome sequenced by Sanger, Roche 454 & Illumina) is 2 tables with rows and columns appearing sequentially while lecturer is discussing corresponding technique. However, in slides PDF only Sanger-related row and column (first ones) are present.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Sorry, Boris, that's not a bug the Coursera staff can fix - you'll have to take it up with Microsoft :-( It's what happens when I save it as a pdf from Powerpoint. It has to do with the use of objects which disappear as opposed to which appear in an animated slide. The main point is that the costs are now not so high with NGS. Best, Nick
Instructor's post : Sorry, Boris, that's not a bug the Coursera staff can fix - you'll have to take it up with Microsoft :-( It's what happens when I save it as a pdf from Powerpoint. It has to do with the use of objects which disappear as opposed to which appear in an animated slide. The main point is that the costs are now not so high with NGS. Best, Nick

Input.threadtitle: online experience (jax.org) does not match week 2 lab
Input.posts:
#1 After following the instructions for finding pax6 gene in informatics.jax.org, I don't see: Thin diagonal blue lines in the bottom panel represent orthologous genes between mouse and human.\xA0 #2 I landed in: Chromosome 2: 105,183,133-106,183,132 and not the range indicated in the lab pdf. So the lab questions didn't apply to the page I was observing, but I think I get the gist of what they're getting at by inspecting the pdf.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
If you clicked on the Pax6 results when you used the Quick Search, the ENSEMBL link will take you to the region specified in the lab. Did you add Human for region comparison? I get this result (today) but I'm no longer seeing the blue lines as described in the lab. Not sure why. However, the green parallegrams connecting the human and mouse regions that are similar are still useful and you can still see the synteny, Gary, see\xA0 http://uswest.ensembl.org/Mus_musculus/Location/Multi?db=core;g=ENSMUSG00000027168;r=2:105183133-106183132;r1=11:31324981-32324980:-1;s1=Homo_sapiens . There was an update to the ENSEMBL DB between the time I posted the lab and now :( Best, Nick

Title: Linking forum posts - bioinfomethods-04-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Gene Order and Coding Strand
Input.posts:
In the lab we compared human and mouse pax6 and the purpose of it is to show us that gene order is often conserved. However, I have a question about the coding strain. In mouse it is on the forward while in human it is reverse. How can the order of genes conserve while the coding strand is not?\xA0
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
They look to be on the same 'side', Sophia. Also, you can tell the direction by the little '>' beside the gene name in gold. Or am I looking at something different than you? Best, Nick
Instructor's post : They look to be on the same 'side', Sophia. Also, you can tell the direction by the little '>' beside the gene name in gold. Or am I looking at something different than you? Best, Nick
Upvotes:
0

Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Gene Order and Coding Strand
Input.posts:
In the lab we compared human and mouse pax6 and the purpose of it is to show us that gene order is often conserved. However, I have a question about the coding strain. In mouse it is on the forward while in human it is reverse. How can the order of genes conserve while the coding strand is not?\xA0
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
They look to be on the same 'side', Sophia. Also, you can tell the direction by the little '>' beside the gene name in gold. Or am I looking at something different than you? Best, Nick
Instructor's post : They look to be on the same 'side', Sophia. Also, you can tell the direction by the little '>' beside the gene name in gold. Or am I looking at something different than you? Best, Nick

0

Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Can't see the blue diagonals lines connecting orthologous genes
Input.posts:
If you can`t see the blue diagonals lines connecting orthologous genes as happened to me , click on Configure this page or on Select species or regions on the left pannel. In the pop-up window, click on the tab Configure Comparison Image (the first tab) and under Comparative features select join genes. If after all this you still can't see the lines, refresh the page. It should work. Hope it helps!
